Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Long-time asymptotics of completely integrable systems with connections to random matrices and partial differential equations
Award.AbstractNarration:
The research side of this project focuses on understanding the long-time asymptotics for a diverse set of models from analysis and mathematical physics. In particular, the principal investigator will concentrate on three projects: (1) the continued study of a discrete version of the defocusing nonlinear Schroedinger equation, in particular, its connections with orthogonal polynomials on the unit circle, Lie-Poisson algebras, and its continuum limits; (2) the study of properties (e.g., expected diagonalization times) of certain random matrix ensembles when considered as initial data for integrable flows such as the Toda lattice and the QR-algorithm; and (3) the study, using Riemann-Hilbert methods, of long-time asymptotics for integrable systems, namely, the Toda lattice and the Korteweg-deVries equation, and for certain nonintegrable perturbations of these systems.

The research topics of this project fall in the wide areas of mathematical physics and partial differential equations, with a particular emphasis on questions related to such well-established mathematical areas as completely integrable systems, random matrices, and their applications to certain numerical algorithms. Partial differential equations emerge in a variety of physical contexts as mathematical models for the time-evolution of certain physical quantities. A particular class of such equations are the so-called completely integrable systems, which are characterized by the fact they satisfy a sufficiently large (in a sense which can be made precise) number of conservation laws. The theory of completely integrable systems has a long and distinguished history. Over the past thirty years, in particular, interest in the field has been fueled on the one hand by the fact that many of the equations known to be completely integrable are obtained as models of fluid dynamics, and on the other hand by the close connections that have been discovered with many fields of pure mathematics, such as Lie algebras or symplectic and Poisson geometry. One of the fundamental goals of the current project is to expand and deepen the understanding of these connections and to widen the class of models to which the techniques of completely integrable theory apply. Hence one aims to describe as fully as possible the solutions to these models and hopefully to gain thereby insights into real-life phenomena. An essential part of the proposal is its educational component, which is centered around the organization of an annual summer school for advanced graduate students and recent Ph.D.'s on various topics of current research interest at the juncture of analysis, partial differential equations, and numerical analysis. All talks in the summer school will be delivered on preassigned articles by the participants. Beyond its broad mathematical impact, the project will allow the principal investigator to expand other educational activities as well. She will support the work of graduate students through advanced courses, seminars, and student research workshops, and she will work with local chapters of the Association for Women In Mathematics (AWM) in the Chicago area to promote the advancement of women in mathematical careers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The PI's interests fall in the wide areas of mathematical physics and partial differential equations, with a particular emphasis on questions related to completely integrable systems and spectral theory for Schroedinger operators.  The PI's work in the last few years has focused on analyzing the behavior of solutions to various equations as time becomes very large and goes to infinity. Understanding this so-called long time behavior of the solutions reveals fundamental aspects of the dynamics being investigated, and is thus an essential part of the mathematical physics endeavor.

Partial differential equations emerge in a variety of physical contexts as mathematical models for the time evolution of certain physical quantities. A particular class of such equations are the so-called completely integrable systems, which are characterized by the fact they satisfy a sufficiently large (in a sense which can be made precise) number of conservation laws. One of the fundamental goals of the theory is to fully describe any solution of a completely integrable system in terms of these conservation laws. Completely integrable theory has a long and distinguished history. Over the past 30 years, in particular, interest in the field has been fueled, on the one hand, by the fact that many of the equations known to be completely integrable are obtained as models of fluid dynamics, and on the other hand by the close connections that have been discovered with many fields of pure mathematics, such as Lie algebras or symplectic and Poisson geometry. 

In a first line of investigation, the PI has been studying the long-time behavior of solutions to the Korteweg-deVries equation (probably the best known completely integrable partial differential equation) and some of its perturbations, namely Fermi-Pasta-Ulam lattices. This is part of a large research project, aimed at revealing, via perturbation theory and Riemann-Hilbert techniques, the behavior of solutions of the 2-dimensional Euler equation of fluid dynamics and of so-called Fermi-Pasta-Ulam lattices in physically-relevant regimes, with the aim of resolving, in these instances, the soliton resolution conjecture. While this project has not yet been completed, several new, intriguing phenomena have been discovered. The analytical and numerical work on this topic continues.

The other important research direction deals with the question of confinement of particles in quantum mechanical and probabilistic contexts. It is well known that in classical mechanics, a particle under the influence of a potential will be confined, for all time, to a region of space provided the potential increases to infinity close to the boundary of that region. On the other hand, a quantum particle can ``tunnel'' through an infinitely high potential barrier with non-zero probability. The question of describing the potentials which will prevent this tunneling from ever occurring, and hence fully confine a particle to a certain region, is one of the classical problems in quantum mechanics. It can be rephrased as the problem of establishing essential self-adjointness for the corresponding Schroedinger operator. Research on this topic over the last fifty years led to various criteria; by revisiting classical techniques and combining them with newer analytical results, I was able, together with a collaborator, to extend these known criteria to a wider, indeed often maximal, class of potentials. The strength of this work lies in the fine, and very robust method of proof, which allows us to go far beyond the basic, quantum mechanical set-up to treat, often for the very first time, a wide variety of other cases: among them are quantum particles with or without spin confined by magnetic fields, and stochastic particles with both weak and strong diffusion. In the latest work, currently being finalized, we are able to even extend our methods and treat relativistic particles with spin ½, by working on  Dirac operators in 2 and 3 dimensions.

Finally, on the educational side, the PI has been mentoring and advising several young researchers. Since the beginning of the grant, the PI has overseen the completion of one very successful PhD thesis, and the beginning of a new one, as well as numerous independent studies and several other graduate research assistantships. This grant has also allowed the PI to fully fund several graduate student workshops and a workshop for women in analysis and partial differential equations, as well as the research visits of several distinguished mathematicians — most of whom gave both introductory lectures for graduate students, and research talks. The PI has also been involved in several important course revisions — from her significant and successful redesign of the Calculus sequence in her department (which was recognized by a university teaching award), to her work on the 4th year undergraduate analysis sequence and several graduate analysis courses.
